Award.AwardTitle: Maryland System Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation 2010-2012 Bridge to the Doctorate - BD Site: University of Maryland-College Park

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University System of Maryland (USM) Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP)
seeks funding to add a fifth cohort of Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Fellows to its current retention
initiatives. The first cohort of BD Fellows matriculated at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County
(UMBC) in the fall of 2005. In fall 2006, the second cohort of fellows enrolled at the University of
Maryland, College Park (UMCP). The third cohort enrolled at UMCP in the fall of 2008 and the fourth
cohort enrolled at UMBC in the fall of 2009. Since the first BD cohort matriculated at UMBC in 2005,
there have been 48 BD Fellows enrolled in STEM graduate programs at UMBC and UMCP. Eleven
students have completed MS degrees and 37 students are still enrolled.
�� INTELLECTUAL MERIT
The proposed activity will provide a cohort of 12 students who have participated in LSAMP Programs, as
undergraduates, the opportunity to receive substantial funding and other critical support to successfully
pursue graduate degrees in diverse STEM fields at one of the nation?s top research universities. The
participants also will have opportunities, early in their academic careers, to conduct cutting-edge research
with top research scientists on the UMCP campus and at national laboratories located in close proximity
to the campus. The following will be required of BD fellows:
? To participate in community meetings and individual advising meetings;
? To apply for the NSF Graduate Student Research Fellowship during the first year;
? To serve as role models to current undergraduate LSAMP students in the process of applying for
graduate school;
? To present research at national or local conferences;
? To participate in the University System of Maryland?s Graduate Research Symposium;
? To attend and present posters at the NSF Joint Annual Meeting (JAM);
? To present research and serve as mentors at the joint LSAMP/LSAMP-BD Research Symposium;
? To participate in various seminars on campus in order to promote professional development and
growth;
? To participate in joint USM BD cohort events such as Summer Success Institute and the Harvest
Dinner.
�� BROADER IMPACTS
Many LSAMP students are members of groups that traditionally have been underrepresented in STEM
fields. The proposed activity will increase the number of such students in the pipeline to earn doctoral
degrees in these fields. In addition, activities are planned that would provide the participants with
information about a variety of STEM career options, and help to motivate some of them to prepare for
careers in the professoriate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Program is committed to strengthening the linkage between the undergraduate and doctoral degree by transitioning previous LSAMP graduates into Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) graduate programs. During the 2010-2012 academic years, twelve LSAMP alumni received fellowships to pursue graduate study at the University of Maryland, College Park (UMD). The goal of the BD program is to increase the number of LSAMP alumni who go on to earn doctoral degrees and choose careers in STEM fields, especially the professoriate.

 Intellectual Merit: The proposed activity provided a cohort of 12 students who have participated in LSAMP Programs as undergraduates, the opportunity to receive substantial funding and other critical support to successfully pursue graduate degrees in diverse STEM fields at one of the nation’s top research universities. BD students also participated in opportunities, early in their academic careers, to conduct cutting-edge research with top research scientists on the UMD campus and at national laboratories located in close proximity to the campus. Some of the research and education activities were:

 

  • BD Monthly Community Meetings
  • BD Advising, Counseling and Follow-up
  • BD Research and Conference Participation
  • Participation in NSF Joint Annual Meeting (JAM) BD Conference
  • Participation in the Joint LSAMP/LSAMP-BD Research Symposium
  • Participation in UMD Professional and Personal Development Seminars 
  

Below were other components of the BD Program:

 BD Project Directors-Faculty Advisors/Graduate Program Staff Partnership.  The BD Project Directors formed partnerships with the academic departments of the BD Fellows to build a stronger connection between the BD program and the academic units.

Funding Commitments Post-BD. In Fall 2010, the Project Directors received written confirmation from each academic department of the 2010-2012 BD Fellows committing funding for the students once BD ended in July 2012.

BD Program Evaluation. Using the original 2009 evaluation protocol, a second evaluation by an external evaluator was completed with the 2010-2012 BD cohort. The overall goal of the evaluation was to examine the experiences of current and past BD fellowship participants to understand the factors that contribute to the success of the students as well as those that impede their progress. Many common themes emerged to show that there are significant barriers that are impeding students’ success in graduate programs. Some of these themes are transition issues, understanding the “norms” of the department, and the importance of mentoring. Some new findings also emerged such as the need for personal development and additional career workshops for participants. Based on the findings of this exploratory study, nine recommendations were offered to assist the BD program with assessing the needs of the students and the program’s initiatives for next year.  

BD Information Dissemination. During the 2010-2012 project, the BD Project Directors disseminated information on the BD Program on the LSAMP website and the BD Cohort listerv.
